me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.time

Class Stopwatch

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.time.Stopwatch

  • public class Stopwatch
extends java.lang.Object
    A stopwatch, capable of stopping AND watching. It's absolutely bind bending how incredibly complex such a thing is.

    To be honest, this code kind of sucks, so... yeah. Not my problem, right?

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

      Constructors

      Stopwatch()
      Create a new Stopwatch.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Stopwatch

        public Stopwatch()
        Create a new Stopwatch.
        See Also:
        now(), start()

    • Method Detail

      • now

        public static Stopwatch now()
        Create a new Stopwatch instance and start it. This is a chain of constructing a new Stopwatch and then calling the start() method.
        Returns:
        a stopwatch started at the current time.

      • start

        public void start()
        Start the stopwatch. This will clear the list of laps as well as ensure the stopwatch isn't stopped. Calling this method essentially resets the stopwatch, meaning it can be used again for other purposes.

      • lap

        public void lap()
        Record a lap using the current time.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Add one final lap to the stopwatch and set the isStopped flag to true, meaning no more timestamps can be added without first calling the start() method again.

      • lap

        public java.lang.String lap(int index)
        Get a String representation of a specified lap.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the lap. (0 = start)
        Returns:
        a string representation of the specified lap.

      • elapsedSince

        public double elapsedSince(int index)
        Get the amount of time elapsed between a specified lap number and the start of the timestamp.
        Parameters:
        index - a number greater than 1, representing the index of the desired lap to calculate.
        Returns:
        the amount of time elapsed between the start and the target lap.

      • laps

        public int laps()
        Get the total amount of laps.

        Please note that the START timestamp is included in this count.

        Returns:
        the total amount of timestamps stored in the stopwatch.

      • elapsed

        public double elapsed()
        Get the total amount of time elapsed between the first timestamp and the last timestamp. Note that this method doesn't have any checks to see whether there's more than a single timestamp - if you only have one timestamp (say you just called the start method and nothing else) this method will then return 0.
        Returns:
        the total amount of time elapsed between the Stopwatch's first and last recorded timestamps. These CAN both be the same.

      • getTimestamps

        public java.util.List<Timestamp> getTimestamps()

      • getTimes

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Double> getTimes()

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Convert the timestamp to a string.

        The general format is as follows: 

         0: (start time)
 1: (lap 1 time)
 2: (lap 2 time)
 3: (lap 3 / stop time)
 Elapsed: (elapsed time)

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of the Stopwatch.
